namedEntities.name: I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The book is a deeply personal and candid exploration of mental health, depression, and self-acceptance, resonating globally with readers struggling with anxiety and societal pressures, especially in South Korea and beyond.

namedEntities.name: Baek Se-hee
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: South Korean author and mental health advocate
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Baek Se-hee's life and death have become symbolic of the intersection between mental health awareness and cultural identity, highlighting how personal vulnerability can lead to widespread societal impact and emotional support.

namedEntities.name: Tteokbokki
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A traditional Korean street food dish made with chewy rice cakes and sweet-spicy sauce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tteokbokki represents a cultural symbol of comfort and emotional sustenance, embodying the idea that simple, everyday pleasures can provide strength during times of emotional hardship.

namedEntities.name: Dysthymia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A mild but long-lasting form of depression
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dysthymia is central to the book's narrative, illustrating how chronic, low-level depression affects daily life and how the book offers empathy and understanding for those experiencing it.

namedEntities.name: Korean Organ Donation Agency
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Organ donation organization in South Korea
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agency's statement that Baek Se-hee donated her organs to save five lives underscores her commitment to helping others and adds a layer of heroism and legacy to her story.

namedEntities.name: Jo Eun Bit
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jo Eun Bit represents a generation of young South Koreans who found emotional relief and self-acceptance through Baek Se-hee’s book, showing its real-world impact on personal mental health.

namedEntities.name: Sangeun Lee
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Sangeun Lee highlights how the book has helped teachers and parents recognize self-criticism in a media-saturated society and promotes self-compassion for students.

namedEntities.name: RM (of BTS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: K-pop group member known for promoting self-love
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: RM’s public sharing of the book demonstrates its influence in mainstream pop culture and its role in normalizing mental health discussions among global youth audiences.

namedEntities.name: Marianna Szucs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Marianna Szucs exemplifies the book’s international reach and emotional resonance, particularly among non-Korean readers seeking connection and validation in their own struggles with depression.

namedEntities.name: Seunghye Sun
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of the Korean Cultural Centre UK
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Seunghye Sun emphasizes the cultural significance of Baek Se-hee’s work in expanding Korean literature and its global relevance in psychological and cultural discourse.

namedEntities.name: Confucian values
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Cultural beliefs emphasizing obedience, righteousness, and social conformity
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Confucian values contribute to the stigma surrounding mental health in South Korea, making Baek Se-hee’s open discussion of emotional struggles particularly impactful and transformative.

namedEntities.name: Korean literature
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Body of literature from South Korea
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The book is a landmark in Korean literature, breaking cultural barriers and offering a unique, intimate perspective on mental health that has broadened the global scope of Korean cultural expression.

namedEntities.name: Mental health awareness
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The book has played a pivotal role in normalizing conversations around depression and anxiety, helping reduce stigma and encourage help-seeking behaviors.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The book 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki' by South Korean author Baek Se-hee, which explores her experiences with dysthymia, anxiety, and self-doubt, became a global sensation in 2018 and sold over a million copies worldwide. Despite her early death at age 35, the book's emotional authenticity and candid reflection on everyday struggles with mental health resonated deeply with young people in South Korea and internationally, especially in the face of societal pressure and Confucian values. Baek's legacy is amplified by her decision to donate her organs, saving five lives, and the book’s widespread influence, including being referenced by global figures like RM of BTS and praised by educators across cultures. The paradoxical title symbolizes the human desire to live even in despair, with tteokbokki representing simple joys that sustain hope and emotional resilience.
title: I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki - why I fell in love with this book
